page.title: 02FRISKNEY LANDSCAPE
page.content: Friskney is in a flat and open area separated by many drains and dykes to prevent flooding. The northern part is in the Fens, then the Tofts and then land reclaimed from the sea. The whole area is fertile arable and double cropping land. The main crops are potatoes, sugar beet, corn and green vegetables. Few hedges line the roads but conservationists are interested in planting trees in field corners and recreational areas. A few cattle graze in the occasional grass field. Three such fields have old moats. The old brickyard has been landscaped and ponds dredged for private fishing. These schemes will add to existing woods e.g. Decoy Wood and provide habitats for wild animals and birds. There is a lack of wild flowers, insects and wildlife near the dykes compared to years gone by.
